text: Making the Marinade Boil some water in a kettle. Pour two cups of water into a bowl. Add the dried Guajillo and Pasilla chiles to the water to rehydrate. Soak them for 15 minutes. Drain them on a paper towel. Put on a pair of food preparation gloves. Cut the stems off the chiles. Slice them vertically and remove the seeds. Grill the tomato, onion and garlic cloves to impart extra flavor to your marinade. Chop the onion in half before grilling. Then, grill till blackened on the edges. Put the tomato, onion, garlic cloves, cumin seed, chipotle chile in Adobo sauce, sea salt and a dash of pepper in a food processor. Add the chopped chiles and one-third cup of hot water. Pulse the mixture until it is smooth. Cut excess fat off your pork roast. Cut it into one-inch (2.5cm) pieces. Place the meat, the pineapple and the marinade in a large plastic sack or bowl. Refrigerate it overnight. Cooking Carne Al Pastor Heat a cast iron skillet or heavy skillet on medium-high heat. Add two tbsp. of vegetable oil to the pan. Drain the marinade from the pork and pineapples.  Fry the meat one to two cups at a time. Stir it a few times to ensure all the sides are a crisp golden brown. It should take about 15 minutes per batch. Add more vegetable oil for each batch. Keep it warm in the oven until you are done cooking the meat and pineapples.  Serving Tacos Al Pastor Heat your corn tortillas in the oven, in a steamer or in a microwave.  Use a large spoon to scoop a helping of pork into a small corn tortilla. You may want to use two tortillas at once to reduce the risk of breaking through the tortilla. Top with finely chopped cilantro and onion. Squeeze with a lime wedge. Serve. You can also top with cotija cheese and salsa.
